On 7 May 2015 at 21:20, kstanley@... [neat]
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
> I'm curious, how do you think evolution with a random uniform mutation distribution
> compares to RMS-Prop or regular SGD?  Would it tend to act like GD and kind of slow
> down on shallow gradient dimensions, or would it be more even-handed like
> RMS-Prop, or perhaps something in the middle?

Random mutation doesn't have that specifc flaw of GD that RMSProp is
solving, namely that GD is really slow escaping locations with very
low gradient. Random search ignores the gradient so can't get stuck in
that way.

RMSProp doesn't ignore the gradient, but it does sort of ignore its
/magnitude/ (but not the sign). I say 'sort of' because fluctuations
in the magnitude do affect the path it takes.

Random search will of course travel in the wrong direction 50% of the
time (w.r.t. a given axis), and it has the same issues around choosing
a good step size, i.e. we have to experimentaly find good weight
mutation deltas. Good step sizes are not discovered automatically.

Finally, random search has no equivalent of RMSProp's 'per variable'
learning rate. Hence it has that problem of trying to use a step size
that is good for all of the variables, but the success of RMSProp
suggests that the 'one step size fits all' approach is problematic.

Colin
